Smite 2 is a definitive upgrade of the first Smite, made with Unreal Engine 5 instead of 3, superior graphics, and a greater variety gameplay wise. It offers a diverse roster of mythological figures from mythologies all over the world brought over and reimagined in an appealing style, as well as tons of fun cosmetics to adorn them. Gameplay wise it is one of the most unique MOBAs out there, sharing a third person perspective that is more familiar to the average gamer yet offering a unique challenging learning curve. Item and built variety is at its peak compared to the first Smite, with multiple builds and Aspects to experiment on and create a playstyle tailored to your taste and new gameplay mechanics being constantly added. The superior engine definitely aids the game, as the visuals are unlike anything before, the new characters have abilities that offer new and exciting gameplay impossible to perform previously, and the game can support a lot more interactions. Last but not least, it is way more generous with its premium currency compared to the first game, with daily log-ins alone providing you with 100 diamonds per week, in addition to events, the daily chest potential, a battle pass that's completely free and the diamonds obtained by leveling up gods, you are gathering currency at a great pace, guaranteeing you to gain your favorite skins even as a free to play.


As of now, the game has a steady update ratio of once per two weeks with smaller tweaks in between them, offering a new god alongside multiple gameplay enhancements and new cosmetics and features. As the game is still in Beta with a constant flow of new content being added almost weekly, expect a lot of bugs to occur, however the team is hotfixing them at a steady pace alongside implementing optimizations for better performance even between the patches. The game is far from finished, with some characters from the original game not being ported yet, extra animations such as death animations missing or advanced social features being absent, but the developers are working on it at a steady, and honestly quite rapid pace. In comparison to its state roughly one year ago, the difference is massive and the work put shows. That being said, the game is only continuing to improve and adds content in a great pace, so if you're looking for a fun game to play with friends or a unique MOBA experience that is closer to traditional 3rd person games, or even if you're a mythology fan and looking for a game to take out your fantasy of gods like Zeus, Ra, Thor, Amaterasu and Wukong clashing together in an arena, this is the game for you, give it a go, you'll quickly realize how fun it is and how good each individual god feels to play. Have fun, and see you on the battlefield.

Overall, I can say its going in the right direction. During alpha I was worried. On one hand, they never delivered on the style they showed in trailers, but that's mostly because players whined about things looked. They are still whining, but Hi-Rez is learning fast not to listen to steam community forums as a source of information.

So lets get to it, shall we?

Story: Maybe I need a better review format for MOBAs. Lets swap this too... Cohesion? Strategy? Vision?

Vision: Hi-Rez is following the standard MOBA format. 3 lanes, 5 roles, 2 teams. Like League and Dota 2, it has a rough jungle, primary objectives, and secondary impactful objectives. Overall, they hit the bare minimum. Since earlier this year to now, it has seen steady improvement. I will always say Smite and Smite 2's jungle feels just... massive. Compared to League, Dota 2, Predecessor, hell even the dead Heroes of the Storm, the distance between lanes feels enormous. Most junglers have decent speed though, so it makes up for it. As far as gods are concerned, each lane has its ups and downs. With a new god every 2 weeks, it feels fresh enough that no lane is particularly boring (I say this having fought for my life to never take jungle). Some gods are... well... awful, but many people look past that and still play them because they are fun and edgy (tsuki, jorm, nemesis). Otherwise, the game is shaping up better than I expected. There was a rough patch at the start that I truly thought it was going to just collapse.

7/10 (You will get more if you can keep the game from collapsing by the time all gods are back)

Graphics: They had a plan, a vision. They made them newer, but what I was promised, what I saw over a year ago.... not here. Bellona's release skin's face is so bad its horrifying. The skins and animations they choose at times just do no resonate or make sense to me. I'm fairly certain Nu Wa has 4 bunny skins, all different enough to actually call them separate skins. Some skills and animations are significantly better. Eset and Daji feel and look amazing. The update to Cupid is fantastic. But oh lord, they promised me beauty and gave me hi-res Hi-rez.

6/10

Music: Its fine. Its a MOBA. Some sound epic and this one, I can say I probably mute it more than I listen to it. I need to listen for the footsteps.

5/10

Combat: Yes and no. So agility relic (as of writing this) has a 20 second CD, thats significantly better what I think was 10s before? But I hate it. Gods that a naturally immobile get a little too much out of it if they know they can, even at 20s. It doesn't seem to improve combat or change combat in any meaningful way other than for people to run away, which is the exact reason combat blink was removed (so people couldn't be cowards). It kinda falls into the same issue as healing. Fight, run away, heal up, repeat. They addressed healing in a good way, removing a lot of its power, but also removing quick investments to get rid of it, but agility relic just makes it a budget combat blink that people will buy if they can justify it due to how strong it is when it is a good choice for the match.
3/10 (if agility relic is present), 7/10 if its not.

Systems: Match store looks good, the ability to pin and share builds is huge. UI isn't horrible, and I am not kicked out of a match but still in it so can't queue like Smite used to do.... for years. However, the store for cosmetics is still awful, and I dislike the entire approach.
8/10

Overall: 6.6/10 so it passes the recommend check. If we completely ignore agility relic. I do feel like its gone in a great direction since Smite 1, and can continue, but I can't predict what Hi-Rez will do, and hopefully it will be meaningful. Because if not, then, why would I continue playing it?

SMITE 1 was one of my most played games of all time, and i can definitely say that me and my friends had a blast the entire time. 

Unfortunately, SMITE 2 feels like an empty shell. I know it is in early development stages currently, but I cant get over that feeling wit there being a drastic cut in the amount of characters that are currently playable. Most of my favorite/most played gods are unavailable in SMITE 2 and it is very disappointing. Them adding one new character every 2 weeks without some kind of roadmap leaves me feeling let down when I see characters like Artio coming before someone like He Bo or Hera. Hell even Set would make me happier. But I get that they need to introduce the characters slowly to keep hype up when a new one is added. 

The gameplay is fun and I actually like the addition of aspects. Some of them are strong and allow you to play off-role with some actual benefit. I almost always have a good time when I am playing with friends or using in-game voice chat to set up a gank or just to have comms, so I cant complain about gameplay. 

But thank god I stopped caring about having cosmetics in games. Some of the stuff they do with the travelers/sagas is just ridiculous. You pay $50 for one skin that has 4-5 different recolors, and I am just not a fan of that. I would be much happier with getting 3-4 cool skins for different gods at the same price point, instead of one cool skin that comes in blue, green, red, and purple. 

With all that being said I do highly recommend this game. It has its flaws of course, but it will never become a great game if people don't give it a chance. If you didn't come from SMITE 1 you won't be missing out on the 70 or so characters that are currently waiting to be added. But god I am getting tired of playing the same characters over and over.

Smite has never been a perfect game, and that's alright. But, honestly, I think Smite 2 is a good direction for the future. Looking at a lot of these negative reviews, it's hard to think that these people are thinking rationally and actually trying to criticize Smite 2. Make of that what you will.

Overall, Smite 2 is quite good for how turbulent it's development has been. Hi-Rez feels like it should be a shell of it's former self, but I'm honestly astounded with how much quality content they put out on a regular basis. The game itself is fun, if you like mythology, there's plenty of that here for you, and it's an absolute blast to play with friends, if you all really get into it.

Smite has been a huge part of my life the last few years, and genuinely, I want this game to succeed and become the best it can be. Don't listen to the negative reviews unless they have valid criticisms, and just give the game a try. I think there's something for everyone to enjoy here! Thanks for reading, and have a nice day!

I've played it since the Alpha. Since then the game has gotten so much better. It'd be fallacious to say otherwise. We didn't use to have dedicated consumable slots, couldn't pick a relic (everyone had only beads), various lighting, visual, and performance updates, etc.

I was skeptical of the tank changes to enable high HP or high PROT styles, but I can say that they do work better than before. Played a full PROT game as Chaac the other day in Arena and got 160k mitigated with a positive KDA. Tanks are definitely still a thing, even with the lower stats on items.

With the addition of a god every 2w it's likely that all gods won't be in the game until 2027. A hard launch date hasn't been confirmed, but it's likely that late 2026 or further in the future is when it will be fully launched for Season 1.

The game has some pros and cons to SMITE 1. I definitely know most of my friends who play this game only really care about it being as 1:1 with SMITE 1, but we all know that simply will never be the case, and is pretty restrictive on the game continuing to develop.

The biggest con right now is the god selection, but, again, that will simply be taken of over time. 

Currently the biggest issue I have with the game is the smaller item pool. Speaking about starters, there obviously will be more added as they have confirmed that branching starters will be coming back in Titan Talks. With respect to normal items: I wish there were more simple stat sticks like Sphere of Negation (just INT and MAG PROT). As it stands they have tried to make almost all items in the game specific as a counter, like the Contagion rework, which largely works, but a simple item build would work much better IMO. The whole "oh you want CDR so you have to sacrifice this tanky thing" does kind of make it annoying. For instance: a full HP build (over 5k HP) likely wont have more than 20 CDR (~ 18% CDR), whereas a full PROT tank can easily have 65 CDR (~ 40% CDR). This basically forces some gods to not be viable full HP wise unless their passives counter the CDR problem. Also some tank's abilities scale with PROT so you are incentivized to do so. The best example I can give is Sylvannus' passive giving him passive CDR reduction per seed collected, so he can play high HP builds. Bacchus' flop scales with PROT so he is disadvantaged playing high HP. The way the tank items are constructed enforce most tanks to play very specific builds or always pick items like Draconic Scale (high HP and really high PROT that comes with PROT scaling on its passive). Regarding squishies (jungle/adc/mage) this isn't really an issue. Those gods have obviously preferred play styles with those styles favoring hybrid or non-hybrid power items respectively.

I'm overall not a fan of actives, but I can understand the reasoning for it, especially in ranked/Conquest. Still wish Meditation Cloak was a relic and not an active item that has moderate stats. Kind of weird that it is specific to Assault as a curio and not all the game modes. Most casuals are 100% against actives. Personally, I wish they weren't in the game simply to make the game "easier/simpler" seeing as most controller players don't even remember they have them or have the buttons to do so.

Definitely a fan of Aspects. Having a way to fundamentally make a support/tank become totally DMG focused is a great change of pace. The Eset tank/healer/shield aspect is amazing (by far my favorite aspect in the game), just as Sylv's ADC aspect is just as cracked. Some are just downright horrible - looking at you Sobek aspect (universally agreed as the most retarded aspect by the community). Overall, most are pretty good though like Ra, Eset, Sylv, Osiris, Thor, etc. They genuinely do add more playstyles to the game.

There are still some horribly unbalanced gods (ATM mainly Xbal or Tsuk) so that's also an issue. However, the team has continued to nerf them and Xbal is largely the only big issue RN. Him being able to deal 1300 DMG by hitting one ability mid game is just way too high. This compounded by the CC Immune escape and blinding ult (with buffs on top of it) simply make him the biggest threat in every game I play (squishy and tank alike).

Regarding skins/graphics of the gods there are some that obviously got waaay more attention than others. If you compare the normal Eset skin to Shadow-skin Cerberus the level of detail is trivially obvious. Eset looks like play dough compared to that skin. Many other characters have this smoothness to them, which I believe is largely due to UE5. Personally, it doesn't bother me to a great degree, since you can't really see that level of detail while playing the game - you can only really see that level of detail in the summary or god builder screen. Hopefully the models are somewhat updated overtime, but as it stands RN most look fairly rubbery (Bacchus main skin for example). I will say though that most of the ported over gods do have more detail in their design as compared to SMITE 1, it's just that the "flatness" is noticeable in many. Again, some skins are amazing, like the Shadow or Radian versions of gods.

Matchmaking seems to still be somewhat of an issue, but I'd say this is likely an issue with accurately defining ELO/MMR to any player. I constantly get matched with people who sometimes don't even know you can buy items, skip buying a starter (even though it has a dedicate item slot in SMITE 2), just 1v3 or 1v5 the whole game, etc. The general skill gap in the gap is very apparent, especially in non-ranked Conquest game modes. Looking back at most of my matches, it's like 1/3 of games are surrenders because 1 or 2 people simply are so much worse at the game that it's impossible to carry someone potentially feeding as hard as they are. It really is that high. I don't think this is anywhere near an accurate representation for all game modes, but I'd say it is for Arena.

I'm someone who spends most of their time playing Arena/Joust and utterly can't stand Conquest (too slow), but I did play a good amount of Siege/Slash in SMITE 1. So, the "randoms are trash" meme is something I encounter so much I could honestly make skits out of it if I cared to record more of my games. I do record about a fifth of my games and have like 100 or so to be uploaded to my YT (just honestly haven't cared enough to upload them).

Overall, this game continues to get better in my view. There are some obvious weak points, as I've just outlined, but the game is still largely enjoyable. It will continue to get better if it stays on its current path. IMO it is already better than SMITE 1 even with the current limitations (gods and items mostly), though the community seems pretty 50:50 split on which one they prefer. Currently SMITE 1 has about 1/5 as many online players as the 2nd one, which should be evidence enough of which game is better.

For starters, 7k+ hours(probably more) on SMITE 1 combined between a plethora of platforms and accounts. 

Ill give this game credit on a few things;

1. The ability animations are TOP NOTCH and they look like you're actually casting a mythical ability.
2. Aspects, while I don't think it outright replaces the freedom of builds that you were capable of in smite 1, the way to modify a gods kit to provide better use for certain rules is a plus
3. SOME of the gods look really nice, don't look to gaudy and even get less scanadelous n got some more clothes.

Thats about all the positive things i can think of when looking back to what changes really stand out to me.
NOW THE NEGATIVES;

1. The UI is a MASSIVE FusterCluck, The UI has been dumbed down in so many aspects from the in game god ability info not telling you cost, damage scaling, cooldown, etc. to the in game store not having a stats button so you can see what your totals are on stats for Int, Stg, Cooldown, lifesteal, etc.
2. Going back to the gods and their appearance, WAY to many gods look like they themselves are emitting light rays that rival the SUN, why does every god need to look like a shiny vampire sitting in the sun, the skin particle effects are terrible and come off pixelated even on the highest settings. they just failed at making anything shiny.
3. Items and god builds, while i like the idea of having the auto builder and it is very useful for new players or returning players that wanna hop in and just hit ability keys mindlessly, the builds are as 2D as it gets, WHY did we have to swap from physical and magical items, one of the FEW things that made SMITE 1 actually unique and then still force gods to build certain ways because they scale off certain things more than others. Seems like a roundabout way of trying to seem more broad in building but not quite so.
4. Monetization, Hi-Rez is going to shut down SMITE 1 eventually we all know that. but how long do you think they will support this game when the cosmetics are so obscenely priced and no one buys?! The "Legacy Gems" being a half off coupon when in all actuality most of the skins without them WILL cost 20 dollars a pop is asinine. That's more than double what skins cost in SMITE 1. 
5. Community, I LOVE SMITE, I've played the game since beta on PC, my first and ONLY MOBA. A lot of the reviews i see are people White Knighting for a company that does not and will not care about them.

Do I recommend you play this game as a SMITE 1 vet? Sure, Its the same game with slightly "Upgraded" Graphics and some new twists on the OG SMITE formula. Do I think its the future the game should be heading for? No. All they had to do was make a SMITE 1 Clone with updated skins and god models, not all the extra BS they think is innovative.
